# Step-by-step guidance, from questions to care
Not sure where to start? We’ve got your back. PfizerForAll breaks things down into simple steps to help you better understand your health, book doctor’s appointments, find ways to save on your Pfizer medications, and more. Let’s get started.
content
## Let’s help you take the next step.
card
### **Find savings options**
If you’ve been prescribed a Pfizer medication, we can help find ways you may be able to save.
[Get started](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/prescription-assistance "Get started")
card
### **Talk to a doctor**
We can help you find a telehealth or in-person appointment through an independent network of healthcare providers and doctors.
[Find a provider](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/talk-to-a-doctor "Find a provider")

If you think your headaches could actually be migraine attacks or feel like your current treatment may not be meeting your needs, we've got your back.

Heading
# Every result and every option matters.
Body
Biomarker testing helps you understand if you have a specific subtype of cancer, giving doctors important insights to help design a treatment plan tailored to you.  
  
Beyond personalized care, testing can also open the door to a clearer understanding of how your cancer will likely behave, and potential clinical trial options — while helping you navigate around treatments that may not be as effective.
Label
Button
Banner Icon
Banner content
## Let’s get you ready to take the next step.
Talking to your doctor about biomarker testing can feel overwhelming, but knowing what to ask can help.
Banner button
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")
Banner theme

image
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_17c3a6092b4e68191a2d6d935f895198b2d52f272.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)

![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_1cef105c19d6ddcc9e582938303e3b64097eb6ee0.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
content
About biomarker testing
### What are biomarkers?
In cancer, biomarkers are small signals in tumor cells, like gene changes or certain levels of proteins, that can show how your cancer behaves and how it may change, grow, or respond to treatment.
Testing for them — through a liquid or tissue biopsy — can help your doctor develop a personalized treatment plan based on your cancer’s unique characteristics.
buttons
content
Types of cancer
## Biomarker testing looks different for every cancer. See how.
card
[Blood Cancer](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/blood "Blood Cancer")
card
[Breast Cancer](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/breast "Breast Cancer")
card
[Colorectal Cancer](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/colorectal "Colorectal Cancer")
card
[Lung Cancer](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/lung "Lung Cancer")
card
[Prostate Cancer](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/prostate "Prostate Cancer")
content
## Let’s go over a few of the basics.
Biomarker testing can make a difference in how you care for your cancer. You probably have questions. We have answers.
card
_Who should get tested?_
### **Newly diagnosed patients or those who are not responding to treatment**
Anyone who’s been newly diagnosed with cancer should ask about biomarker testing, but it’s especially important for those with a type of cancer that grows or changes quickly. It’s also critical if your cancer hasn’t been responding to treatment, since the test results can help guide a new way forward.
card
_How does testing happen?_
### **Tests include two types of biopsies: liquid or tissue, based on cancer type and stage**
Depending on your cancer type and its stage, your doctor will order a tissue biopsy or liquid biopsy. Tissue biopsies, considered the gold standard, sample the tumor for detailed testing. Liquid biopsies use fluids, like blood, for faster, less invasive tests, but they can also be less sensitive.
card
_What will the results tell me?_
### **Your results offer a range of insights for your team that can inform your care plan and more**
Testing can reveal known biomarkers that show how your cancer is behaving, and how it may change or grow over time and respond to treatment. Even if no biomarkers show up in your test, the results can still help your care team identify care options or potential clinical trials to enroll in.
card
_When do I talk to my doctor?_
### **After a diagnosis, before treatment starts, or if you’re not responding to treatment**
Ask about biomarker testing at diagnosis, when discussing treatment options, or if your cancer stops responding to treatment. You may have had testing already; if you’re not sure, you can ask your doctor at your next appointment.
Eyebrow
Let’s check in
Question
Do you feel ready to talk to your doctor about biomarker testing?

  * Not helpful

Talk to your doctor
### Your tailored treatment plan really begins with a conversation.
Asking about biomarker testing early can make a big impact on how you approach your care. Even if the process is unfamiliar, your doctor is there to help you understand your options and move forward with clarity.
buttons
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")
_content_
## Still have questions?
_Card_
### Can I get biomarker testing if I've already started another treatment?
Yes, biomarker testing can help you and your care team make decisions about your entire treatment plan, including your existing care. It’s especially critical if your cancer hasn’t been responding to your current treatment, since the test results can help guide a new way forward — so it’s never too late to ask about.
* * *
* * *
_card_
### What is the difference between a tissue and liquid biopsy?
Tissue biopsies are the gold standard for biomarker testing. While they’re more invasive than a liquid biopsy, they also go much deeper in the type of information they’re able to identify from a tumor. They can be done in an outpatient setting, with a needle biopsy, or in a hospital for inpatient procedures that surgically remove a small piece of tumor.
Liquid biopsies are typically done in a clinic or your doctor’s office since they’re less invasive, faster to complete, and easier to repeat than tissue biopsies. They generally use samples of your blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, and even saliva to test for biomarkers.
After your samples are collected, they’ll be sent to a specialized lab where pathologists will analyze genetic and molecular changes.
_card_
### How long will it take to get my biomarker test results?
Timing can vary depending on your test type and the individual labs involved. Reported laboratory turnaround times show that the majority of testing is returned within 10 business days.
_card_
### What if my tumor doesn't have any actionable biomarkers?
If your test results reveal a biomarker with no matching treatments, there are a few next steps you may be able to take:
  * If your test reveals no biomarkers, or the results are unclear, ask your doctor when you may be able to test for biomarkers again
  * If your test results show biomarkers that do not match any targeted treatments, your doctor may help you enroll in a potential clinical trial
  * If there are no targeted treatments or clinical trials available for your biomarkers, your doctor may recommend traditional treatment methods like chemotherapy, radiation, or surgery


Additionally, new biomarker-related treatments are always in development, so even more care options may be available in time.
_card_
### Will I need to get retested?
Depending on how well your current treatment is working, your doctor may want to have you retested for any changes to your disease and the biomarkers that may show up.
Since changes can occur over time, it can reveal the way your tumor is growing or changing, or if it’s developing a resistance to treatment.
New biomarkers can indicate alternative treatment options that may work more effectively.
_card_
### Will my biomarker testing be covered by insurance?
Your care team can help you understand your payment options, including insurance.
In general, private insurance companies will cover the cost of testing* when it’s deemed medically necessary, but [some states](https://www.fightcancer.org/what-we-do/access-biomarker-testing/?exitCode=pfa "some states") may require insurance providers to cover biomarker testing based on clinical guidelines.
Additionally, some labs may offer financial support, while advocacy and patient support groups may offer affordability programs.
_body: *Not including any deductibles and co-payments_
_card_
### If I test positive for a biomarker, should my family members also get tested?
Not all biomarkers are based on genetic disposition, so ask your doctor if your specific biomarkers are indicative of a genetic link — and if your family may be candidates for screening or other testing.

pages.title: Pneumococcal Pneumonia Vaccine | PfizerForAll™
pages.description: Learn about Pneumococcal Pneumonia and available vaccines that may be right for you
pages.summary: Pneumococcal pneumonia is a bacterial lung infection that can be serious and can strike without warning. Breathing difficulties, high fever, and an ongoing cough can disrupt your life for weeks. It can even put you in the hospital. People age 50+ are at a higher risk.

Pneumococcal Pneumonia
Heading
# Pneumococcal pneumonia doesn’t care what season it is.
Body
Pneumococcal pneumonia is a bacterial lung infection that can be serious and can strike without warning. Breathing difficulties, high fever, and an ongoing cough can disrupt your life for weeks. It can even put you in the hospital. People age 50+ are at a higher risk.
Button
[Book a vaccine](https://www.vaxassist.com/pfizer-for-all/schedule?exitCode=pfa "Book a vaccine")[Check your eligibility](https://www.vaxassist.com/pfizer-for-all/eligibility?exitCode=pfa "Check your eligibility")
content
## Here’s what to know about the vaccine.
card
_What is it?_
### A single shot
As you get older, your body’s natural defenses begin to weaken. This can make it easier to catch illnesses like pneumococcal pneumonia, which is caused by bacteria. Fortunately, there are vaccines that can help protect you—one shot for adults and a series of shots for babies.
card
_Who’s it for?_
### Age 50+  
Age 19+
#### with existing conditions
According to the CDC, you can get vaccinated at any time, if you’re eligible. This includes anyone age 50+ or those age 19+ with existing medical conditions, such as asthma, COPD, chronic heart disease, and diabetes.
card
_Possible side effects?_
Soreness
Fever
Headache
Most side effects are mild and go away on their own within a few days. They include redness or soreness where you got the shot, fever or chills, loss of appetite, feeling tired, headache, muscle aches, or joint pain.
Content
# If you want to learn more, take a look at this.
Image

## Still have questions?
_Card_
### How often do I need a pneumococcal pneumonia vaccine?
Unlike the flu vaccine, you don't need to get a pneumococcal vaccination every year. Talk with your doctor to learn more.
**Updated** Pneumococcal pneumonia vaccination in adults explained _4 min read_[https://pfizerforallcomna-main-page.web.pfizer/vaccines/education/what-is-the-pneumococcal-vaccine-for](https://www.pfizerforall.com/vaccines/education/what-is-the-pneumococcal-vaccine-for "https://pfizerforallcomna-main-page.web.pfizer/vaccines/education/what-is-the-pneumococcal-vaccine-for")
* * *
_card_
### Are there different types of pneumococcal pneumonia vaccines?
Yes, there are different kinds of pneumococcal pneumonia vaccines. Each one has different coverage in terms of what types are included. All pneumococcal pneumonia vaccines help reduce the risk of pneumococcal disease.
_card_
### Can I get the pneumococcal pneumonia vaccine at the same time as the flu vaccine, or other respiratory vaccines?
Yes, you can get a pneumococcal pneumonia vaccination the same time you get your other respiratory vaccines, including the flu vaccine. Each vaccine is given with its own syringe, and if possible, in a different spot on the body.
_card_
### How much does a pneumococcal pneumonia vaccination cost?
If you have insurance, including Medicare or Medicaid, your pneumococcal pneumonia vaccination may be available at no additional cost to you. Please contact your insurance company for specific cost information for this vaccine. People without insurance may pay the list price per dose, plus any additional pharmacy charges that may apply.
_card_
### Where can I go to get a pneumococcal pneumonia vaccine?
On [VaxAssist](https://www.vaxassist.com/pfizer-for-all?exitCode=pfa "VaxAssist"), it’s easy to find a nearby pneumococcal pneumonia vaccine location and book an appointment with participating providers.
content

![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/media_18de5d620354b7b69cec6205cc0d8e6be7f299c45.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
Mobile Image
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/media_1462588d5c5574e39fbc5ac5fff0b0109ae551a4d.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
Heading
# A new offer to help Americans save.
Body
For eligible patients who choose to self-pay, there's now an easier way to save. We're working with GoodRx to help you get significant savings on list prices on over 30 Pfizer brands.*
Label
*Savings vary by product. No membership fees. This is not health insurance. Terms & conditions apply. [See here](https://www.goodrx.com/go/pfizer?exitCode=pfa "See here").
Content
## It just takes 3 simple steps:
list
## **1. Find your medication**
Select the dosage, quantity, and pharmacy that matches your Pfizer prescription.
list
## **2. Get your coupon**
Print, save, or text yourself the free coupon from GoodRx.
list
## **3. Save on your order**
Show the pharmacist your coupon at checkout to apply your savings.
content

## Still have questions?
_card_
### Self-pay isn’t right for me, how else can I save?
**If you want to pay with insurance:**  
If you're taking Pfizer medication and have private insurance, you may be eligible for a Pfizer co-pay card to help you start saving at participating pharmacies.*
**You may be eligible for financial assistance:**  
If you are uninsured or have Government insurance, Pfizer RxPathways can help you learn about financial assistance options, if available.
_*Terms and conditions apply. See full terms and conditions on each respective brand's website. Cards will be accepted only at participating pharmacies. Cards are not health insurance. No membership fees._
_card_
### What is GoodRx and how does it work?
GoodRx is a fast, free and easy-to-use digital platform that helps Americans find the lowest prescription prices in their neighborhood.
For eligible patients who choose to self-pay, Pfizer is working with GoodRx to help you get significant savings on list prices for over 30 Pfizer brands.*
Patients can simply visit [GoodRx.com](https://www.goodrx.com/go/pfizer?utm_source=pfe&exitCode=pfa "GoodRx.com"), search for their Pfizer medicine and prescribed dose, download the coupon, and present it at the pharmacy counter or use it to pay online ahead of pickup.
_*Savings vary by product. No membership fees. This is not health insurance. Terms & conditions apply. [See here](https://www.goodrx.com/go/pfizer?exitCode=pfa "See here")._

## Not sure where to begin? Let’s find the option that meets your needs.
card
_Want to pay with insurance?_
### A co-pay card could help cut your costs
Search for your prescription to see if you qualify for a Pfizer savings card, and start paying less at the pharmacy each month.
[Look up my medication](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/prescription-assistance#spend-less-however-you-want-to-pay "Look up my medication")
card
_Want to self-pay?_
### You can still save if you don’t want to use insurance
For eligible patients who choose to self-pay, discounts on over 30 Pfizer brands are available through GoodRx.
[Learn more about self-pay](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/self-pay "Learn more about self-pay")
card
_Need financial support?_
### You may be eligible for financial assistance
If you are uninsured or have Government insurance, Pfizer RxPathways can help you learn about financial assistance options, if available.
image
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/media_153f07715ae41cb43dc2c90296e4b84ea84178875.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
image mobile
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/media_1eaf95a614b99a9eeacb060d56912fc1e3fcfb87b.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
partner logo
content
### When you hear the words “prior authorization,” here’s what to know.
For some medications, your doctor may need to get approval from your insurance provider before the prescription can be filled. This is also known as a “prior authorization.”
Without this approval, your insurance plan may not pay for your medication.
## **Submit**
Your doctor submits forms to your insurance company explaining why you need the medicine.
## **Review**
Your insurance company reviews the request, usually within 2 weeks. But some medications can take up to 30 days for review.
## **Decide**
Next, a decision is made. If the request is denied, your doctor can appeal.
## **Order**
Once your medication is approved, it then goes to your pharmacy to be filled.
_content_
## Still have questions?
_card_
### How does prior authorization work?
Your healthcare provider will submit a prior authorization to your health insurance company. Then, your insurance provider can either approve the request, deny the request, ask for more information, or recommend a less expensive, but comparable treatment option.
_card_
### Why do some medications or procedures require prior authorization?
Health insurance companies have long used prior authorization as a way to control their costs. Without prior authorization, your insurance plan may not pay for your medication, and you would be responsible for the full cost.
_card_
### What is GoodRx and how does it work?
GoodRx is a fast, free and easy-to-use digital platform that helps Americans find the lowest prescription prices in their neighborhood.
Pfizer is working with GoodRx to help you get significant savings on list prices for over 30 Pfizer brands.*
Patients can simply visit [GoodRx.com](https://www.goodrx.com/go/pfizer?utm_source=pfe&exitCode=pfa "GoodRx.com"), search for their Pfizer medicine and prescribed dose, download the coupon, and present it at the pharmacy counter or use it to pay online ahead of pickup.
_*Savings vary by product. No membership fees. This is not health insurance. Terms & conditions apply. See [here](https://www.goodrx.com/go/pfizer?exitCode=pfa "here")._

## We have 2 easy ways to get started.
card
### Why choose in-person care?
Sometimes getting on the same page starts with being in the same room. When you want to get care that's face-to-face, we can help you find a provider nearby.
card
### Why choose telehealth?
Telehealth makes care simpler. You can talk to a doctor from wherever you are, often with shorter wait times.
image
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/media_104defb1750d7c2cd47d16aedad5f9d9739c71da2.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)

content

Learn about vaccines for pneumococcal pneumonia, COVID-19, RSV, and flu. You can even check which ones you’re eligible for and where to schedule one nearby.

# When COVID-19 symptoms start, the clock is ticking.
Cough, fever, or fatigue? It could be COVID-19. If you’re at higher risk of developing severe illness, prescription medications exist, but they must be taken within the first 5 days of symptoms.
[Take the risk assessment](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/risk-assessment/ "Take the risk assessment")
On this page
  * [Why early action matters](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/treatment-education#why-early-action-matters)
  * [Testing and treatments](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/treatment-education#testing-and-treatments)
  * [Talk to your doctor](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/treatment-education#talk-to-your-doctor)


Why early action matters
### More people are at risk of severe COVID-19 than you might think.
This includes people aged 50 or older and those with certain health conditions like diabetes, depression, and heart conditions.
75%
of adults in the US have at least one risk factor for progression to severe COVID-19.
_Source: AM J Prev Cardiol_
## Learn more about COVID-19 treatment and risk factors.
  * ![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_10b308b456bb60ec2de54ebd8c3ea89b6a6d20bbe.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
Treatment 
### **Factors that put you at high risk for severe COVID-19**
5 min read
[Read now](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/risk-factors-for-severe-covid-19 "Read now")
  * ![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_1140157aaa96f68b989a63d21f1305f62a698c3aa.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
Treatment 
### COVID-19 and chronic conditions: what you need to know
4 min read
[Read now](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/covid-19-information-for-underlying-medical-conditions "Read now")
  * ![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_1bf0f5e64513c17edb4293cdccbf448e4b5417213.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
Treatment 
### What to do if you test positive for COVID-19
5 min read
[Read now](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/what-to-do-if-positive-for-covid-19 "Read now")


![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-left.svg)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-right.svg)
Slide 1 of 3
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_17dbeec8de8d4c043685fd87517b29a3207c31546.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_1e5926fd5ceb0dc1a5d838845b7440f2e44b5e33b.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
### What happens when COVID-19 turns severe?
Hospitalization, intensive care, ventilator use. Even if your symptoms are mild now, they could get worse quickly and are more likely to progress if you have certain risk factors:
  * Being age 50 or older
  * Certain health conditions
  * Overweight/Obesity
  * Certain mental health conditions
  * Certain disabilities


### The first 5 days matter most.
If you start feeling sick, talk to your doctor right away. For those at higher risk of developing severe COVID-19, prescription medications exist, but you must start within the first 5 days of symptoms.
### Watch out for the early signs.
The common cold, flu, and COVID-19 can all look alike. So if you start feeling sick, look out for symptoms like cough, fever, chills, fatigue and body aches, trouble breathing, or a new loss of smell.
[Take the risk assessment](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/risk-assessment/ "Take the risk assessment")
Test your knowledge
The common cold, flu, and COVID-19 all have similar symptoms.
True
False
Testing and treatments
## Need a COVID-19 test?
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_1b1890cff9b07e47d2cf80ae5a19659b231ddb0d1.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
### Find the nearest location  
to get tested in person.
[Get tested at Walgreens](https://www.walgreens.com/testandtreat/testing?ext=pfizerforall&exitCode=pfa "Get tested at Walgreens")[Get tested at Walmart](https://www.walmart.com/cp/test-treat/4097505?povid=OMNISRV_D_i_GLOBAL_Nav_ServicesNav_HW_4097505_SuperDepartment_ClinicalServices_Testing&Treatment_1332399668=&exitCode=pfa "Get tested at Walmart")
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_10548f703664095658364c2c6e4279d464c507b2a.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
### Order online and have a  
test delivered as early as today.
[Shop tests on Amazon](https://www.amazon.com/s?k=covid+test&crid=1QT1JZDD88484&sprefix=%2Caps%2C89&ref=nb_sb_ss_recent_1_0_recent&exitCode=pfa "Shop tests on Amazon")[Shop tests on Instacart](https://www.instacart.com/store/brands/pfizer-for-all?exitCode=pfa "Shop tests on Instacart")
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_16ee4edfcfcbd9e96b13027dddd9b5d81c037790f.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_143abbf1241b66d688516145a2c15d50620dcb4ce.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
### Why early treatment matters.
Prescription medications are available to treat COVID-19 for those at higher risk of severe illness. They must be taken within 5 days of your first symptoms, so contact your doctor as soon as possible to see if treatment may be right for you.
[Explore a Pfizer treatment option](https://www.paxlovid.com/?exitCode=pfa "Explore a Pfizer treatment option")
Talk to your doctor
## The best next step starts with a conversation.
  * ### **Schedule an appointment**
At the first sign of COVID-19 symptoms, contact your doctor. If you don't have a doctor, you can [schedule a telehealth appointment](https://patientfirst.wheel.health/?exitCode=pfa "schedule a telehealth appointment").
  * ### Prepare for your visit
Write down your symptoms, health conditions, and all medications you're taking in the [doctor discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/discussion-guide.pdf "doctor discussion guide"). Don't forget even small details can be important.
  * ### Ask about treatment and eligibility
If you have COVID-19, ask your doctor if prescription medications may be right for you. The sooner you know, the sooner you can take action.


![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-left.svg)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-right.svg)
Slide 1 of 3

![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/media_17f43b511e5fefbc714a27fcca831b0ba8f95f721.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)

**IN THE FIGHT AGAINST CANCER**
# EVERY  
SCREEN  
MATTERS
Early detection saves lives.  
It only takes ~30 seconds to get your personalized screening guide.
[Get started](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/cancer-screening/assessment "Get started")
[Retake](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/cancer-screening/assessment "Retake")
[Return to guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/cancer-screening/guide "Return to guide")
Your information is secure, protected, and used  
to inform your screening recommendations.
## Cancer screening can make a difference
## **Catch things early**
When detected early, cancer survival rates can reach up to 99% for certain cancers.
## **Spot silent issues**
Screenings can often find issues long before symptoms appear, so it's important to be proactive.
## **Make it a routine**
Screenings can be included in your annual wellness checks, so you can prioritize your long-term health.
## Proudly supporting
We’re proud to support and amplify the [American Cancer Society’s](https://www.cancer.org/cancer/screening/get-screened.html?exitCode=pfa "American Cancer Society’s") efforts to help more people get screened for cancer — because early detection is crucial. That’s why we developed our screening guide based on their cancer screening guidelines.
## What screenings are there?
American Cancer Society recommends five types of routine screenings.
  * ### **Breast screening**
Women 40+ are recommended to get a mammogram. You can schedule your appointment directly, without needing a doctor referral.
[Schedule your screening](https://www.pfizerforall.com/#schedule-breast-screening "Schedule your screening")
  * ### **Cervical screening**
Women 21-65 are recommended to get HPV tests. You can schedule your appointment directly, without needing a doctor referral.
[Schedule your screening](https://www.pfizerforall.com/#schedule-cervical-screening "Schedule your screening")
  * ### **Colorectal screening**
Adults 45+ are recommended to get colorectal checks, like at-home stool tests or a colonoscopy. If a colonoscopy is needed, your doctor will give you a referral.
[What to ask your doctor](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/cancer-screening/talk-to-your-doctor/colorectal "What to ask your doctor")
  * ### **Lung screening**
People ages 50–80 with a smoking history are recommended to get a low-dose CT scan. This check requires a doctor referral.
[What to ask your doctor](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/cancer-screening/talk-to-your-doctor/lung "What to ask your doctor")
  * ### **Prostate screening**
Men 50+ or those with family history are recommended to get a prostate check. This check requires a doctor referral for a blood test.
[What to ask your doctor](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/cancer-screening/talk-to-your-doctor/prostate "What to ask your doctor")


![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-left.svg)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-right.svg)
Slide 1 of 5
## Schedule your screening
Book your screening directly through Zocdoc or find screening locations near you via the American Cancer Society.
[Book on Zocdoc](https://www.zocdoc.com/search?reason_visit=252&searchOriginator=paid&utm_medium=PPA&exi=&exitCode=pfa "Book on Zocdoc")
[Find on American Cancer Society](https://getscreened.cancer.org/?exitCode=pfa "Find on American Cancer Society")
## Schedule your screening
Book your screening directly through Zocdoc or find screening locations near you via the American Cancer Society.
[Book on Zocdoc](https://www.zocdoc.com/search?searchOriginator=paid&dr_specialty=104&reason_visit=130&u=&exitCode=pfa "Book on Zocdoc")
[Find on American Cancer Society](https://getscreened.cancer.org/?exitCode=pfa "Find on American Cancer Society")
## What does it cost?
I have insurance
For most insurance plans, routine screenings are fully or mostly covered. Ask your health insurance about coverage for cancer screenings.
I don’t have insurance
If you need a cancer screening but don’t have health insurance, your local county or state health department may have programs available to help with costs. To find useful information, visit [Costs and Insurance Coverage for Cancer Screening │ American Cancer Society](https://www.cancer.org/cancer/screening/cancer-screening-costs-insurance-coverage.html?exitCode=pfa "Costs and Insurance Coverage for Cancer Screening │ American Cancer Society"). You can also find screening locations near you by using the [American Cancer Society Screening Location Finder](https://getscreened.cancer.org/?exitCode=pfa "American Cancer Society Screening Location Finder").
This screening guide developed by Pfizer is based on information provided by the individual and is intended to offer educational insights about the potential eligibility for cancer screening according to guidelines from the [American Cancer Society (ACS)](https://www.cancer.org/cancer/screening/get-screened.html?exitCode=pfa "American Cancer Society \(ACS\)"), last revised on December 4, 2025. T**his guide is not a diagnostic tool and is not intended to replace discussion with a healthcare professional.** ACS does not own, operate, endorse, control, recommend, or assume liability for this screening guide, nor does it receive any personally identifiable information or personal health information of individuals from Pfizer. ACS does not endorse any company, products, or services or any particular healthcare providers.

![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/media_190e2ba9ef130a664dcfc1d5b9275c9a562c4b21e.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium) ![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/media_1aaa82c91baa8450da424aee22792a677113a2390.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)

... / [Home](https://www.pfizerforall.com/) / [Migraine](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/) / Treatment
# Migraine doesn't just hurt. It can hold your life back.
Migraine attacks can hit harder than regular headaches. Migraine is a condition rooted in the brain that can disrupt not only how you feel but also what you can do. It isn't curable, but it can be managed.
[Is your treatment meeting your needs?](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/quiz "Is your treatment meeting your needs?")
On this page
  * [Learn about treatments](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/treatment#learn-about)
  * [Talk to a doctor](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/treatment#talk-to-a-doctor)


## Learn about treatments
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/media_1caa3437aed1d9d924e9f1f120792e020b9a1a3f3.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
Treatment 
## **Migraine isn’t curable, but it can be managed.**
There are two main approaches to migraine care: treat attacks when they start (acute care) and aim to prevent them before they happen (preventive care).
4 min read
[Read now](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/education/acute-and-preventive-migraine-treatment "Read now")
## See how these types of migraine treatments may be able to help you.
[Explore a Pfizer treatment option](https://www.nurtec.com/?exitCode=pfa "Explore a Pfizer treatment option")
  * ### **Gepants**
Gepants were the first oral CGRP receptor blockers that were developed for the acute treatment of migraine.
  * ### **Triptans**
Triptans are specifically made to treat migraine attacks. They may help reduce pain and other symptoms when taken.
  * ### **Anti-Nausea**
These “anti-sickness” medications can help relieve the nausea and vomiting that can come with a migraine attack.
  * ### **Pain Relievers**
Pain medication, such as aspirin or ibuprofen, can also treat migraine. These medications work best when taken right when symptoms start.


![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-left.svg)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-right.svg)
Slide 1 of 4
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/media_12cb09af5107978b657db72362819163148b124a7.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/media_15d1e674d4fe69d20d39c6919b5201a0dfb8df0a0.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
### See if it might be time to change up your treatment.
Answer 5 questions to help understand if your migraine medication is meeting your needs.
[Take the quiz](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/mtoq-questionnaire/question-1 "Take the quiz")
Talk to a Doctor
## Ready to talk to a doctor? We can help.
Get the most out of your doctor visit by answering the questions below. Then schedule an online consultation to find the best treatment for you.
[Connect through telehealth](https://upscriptcare.com/products/migraine?t=migraine_s2%3FexitCode%3Dpfa&exitCode=pfa "Connect through telehealth")
  * ### **Treatments**
What types of medications have you taken in the past? How happy are you with your current treatment?
  * ### **Frequency & Patterns**
How many days per month do you experience migraine attacks?  
Have your attacks changed at all over the past 3 to 6 months?
  * ### **Symptoms & Severity**
What are symptoms like before and during an attack? How bad is it and how long do the attacks typically last?
  * ### **Triggers**
What sort of triggers seem to bring on your attacks (eg, foods, stresses, hormones, menstruation, light/high altitude, lack of sleep, weather changes, etc.)?
  * ### **Family History**
Does anyone else in your family experience migraine attacks?


![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-left.svg)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-right.svg)
Slide 1 of 5
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/media_1787d5e1a9ed8d814a3cdcf714d4a754140f7d3cc.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/media_11f469365d45b893776f9be293905359da6c4eb19.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
### Save on your prescribed Pfizer medications and get support when you need it.
[Explore prescription assistance](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/prescription-assistance "Explore prescription assistance")

# Step-by-step guidance, from questions to care
Not sure where to start? We’ve got your back. PfizerForAll breaks things down into simple steps to help you better understand your health, book doctor’s appointments, find ways to save on your Pfizer medications, and more. Let’s get started.
## Let’s help you take the next step.
### **Find savings options**
If you’ve been prescribed a Pfizer medication, we can help find ways you may be able to save.
[Get started](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/prescription-assistance "Get started")
### **Talk to a doctor**
We can help you find a telehealth or in-person appointment through an independent network of healthcare providers and doctors.
[Find a provider](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/talk-to-a-doctor "Find a provider")
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/media_1a41c4f58bbdaa4fbb136ed20e9d295a9c8cd2614.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium) ![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/media_10558c2e11f9761244fbc3efdb18f8e7f38a939c4.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
## Learn what’s behind each condition and how to help manage it.
### **COVID-19**
For those at high risk of severe COVID-19, prescription medications are available, but you have to start treatment within 5 days of your first symptoms.
[Find out more](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/treatment-education "Find out more")
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/media_185d50cfde74cab2221d6927421bc2d5bbeeb42a2.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium) ![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/media_1259c772cfbe0aa0ac17fcfb8faf874e8a12b4327.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
## Learn what’s behind each condition and how to help manage it.
### **Migraine**
If you think your headaches could actually be migraine attacks or feel like your current treatment may not be meeting your needs, we've got your back.
[Find out more](https://www.pfizerforall.com/migraine/treatment "Find out more")
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-left.svg)
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/icons/chevron-right.svg)

![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/media_18b34612962eab73a70d3ae42f928d535532246bf.jpg?width=750&format=jpg&optimize=medium)
### An easier way for more Americans to save.
For eligible patients who choose to self-pay, new discounts are available. Explore significant savings off list prices on over 30 Pfizer brands. Get started now.*
_*Savings vary by product. No membership fees. This is not health insurance. Terms & conditions apply. [See here](https://www.goodrx.com/go/pfizer?exitCode=pfa "See here")._

### We’re committed to helping you afford your Pfizer prescriptions.
From co-pay cards to self-pay savings and help navigating insurance approvals, we’ll guide you to the right support. And if you’re eligible for our programs, we’ll help you get the Pfizer medicines you need.
[Explore ways to save](https://www.pfizerforall.com/savings-support/prescription-assistance "Explore ways to save")

content
## Get the most out of your ATTR-CM visit.
card
###  **Get a personalized**  
**ATTR-CM discussion guide**
Just answer a few questions about your symptoms, conditions, and medical history to get a doctor discussion guide you can use to start the conversation.
[Take the quiz](https://www.pfizerforall.com/attr-cm/discussion-guide/ "Take the quiz")
card
###  **Learn more about**  
**ATTR-CM**
It’s a rare, progressive condition meaning it gets worse over time.
[Get started](https://www.pfizerforall.com/attr-cm/ "Get started")
_content_
## Still have questions?
_Card_
### **Why is it important to speak with a doctor if you have a family history of heart failure?**
Because the hereditary type of ATTR-CM is passed to family members.
_Card_
### **Why is ATTR-CM sometimes underdiagnosed or misdiagnosed?**
Awareness among patients, and even physicians, remains low, which results in ATTR-CM being significantly underdiagnosed. Underdiagnosis and delayed diagnosis occur because the symptoms of ATTR-CM mimic those of other more common causes of heart failure.
_Card_
### **What are some common symptoms of ATTR-CM?**
In addition to heart failure, carpal tunnel, stomach issues, lumbar spine stenosis, peripheral neuropathy, and others.

_Colorectal screening_
# What to ask your doctor
Bring these questions to your appointments or keep them on your phone. You don’t need to ask them all—just pick the ones that make you feel prepared and supported.
[Download](https://www.pfizerforall.com/assets/pdf/colorectal-no-family-history.pdf "Download")
content
###### **Choosing the right test**
  * What are all my screening options, and which do you recommend for me?
  * What are the pros and cons of colonoscopy versus stool-based tests?
  * How accurate is each test option?


content
###### **About your colonoscopy**
  * What preparation is required, and how can I make it easier on myself?
  * Will I be sedated, and will I need someone to drive me home?
  * What are the risks of colonoscopy?
  * What happens if you find polyps during the procedure?
  * If polyps are removed, will my insurance still cover it as preventive screening?


content
###### **About stool tests**
  * How do I collect the sample correctly?
  * Where do I send it, and how long until I get results?
  * What does a positive result mean, and what would happen next?


content
###### **After screening**
  * When will I get my results, and how will you share them with me?
  * How often do I need to repeat this screening?
  * What symptoms should I watch for between screenings?

Lung Cancer
Heading
# When lung cancer changes life, testing can change its care.
Body
Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths in the US, which is why early, effective care matters. That’s where biomarker testing comes in.  
  
It helps doctors move from one-size-fits-all care to personalized treatment plans, like targeted therapy — a type of cancer treatment that targets the ways cancer cells grow, divide, and spread. Even if you get tested and don’t have any biomarkers, that’s ok. It’s still important for getting your care team more informed and can help them evaluate treatment options.
content
Did you know?
### Your treatment plan can be based on your biomarkers.
You may recognize some of these biomarkers from your own chart. There are many biomarkers for lung cancer. Talk to your doctor about testing to see what they may mean.
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")

content
About biomarker testing
## What are lung cancer biomarkers?
Cancer biomarkers are small signals in tumor cells, like gene changes or certain levels of proteins, that can show how your cancer behaves and how it may change, grow, or respond to treatment. Even two people with the same type of lung cancer can have very different biomarkers.
By testing for them, your care team can create an individualized treatment plan — and adjust it if the disease changes over time. In lung cancer, a few common biomarkers include PD-L1, _KRAS_ , _EGFR_ , _ALK_ , and _BRAF_.
content
## Let’s go over a few of the basics.
Biomarker testing can make a difference in your lung cancer care. You probably have questions. We have answers.
card
### Who should get tested?
Anyone who's been newly diagnosed with lung cancer, or is starting new or alternative care, should ask about biomarker testing.
It’s important for lung cancer because certain sub types can spread quickly. By looking at the makeup of your cancer, testing can help predict whether the tumor will grow slowly or aggressively — and can help your doctor assess the risk of recurrence if you've already had surgery to remove tumor tissue.
card
### What will my results show?
In lung cancer, biomarker testing can show your subtype and reveal if you have actionable biomarkers that can guide more personalized care.
Two main types of biomarkers can highlight important results: mutations that help your cancer cells grow, and immune-related biomarkers that tell your doctor how you may respond to immunotherapy.
Even if your results turn out inconclusive or negative for biomarkers, testing can still help your doctor evaluate your care options and let you know if you need to get tested again.
card
### Does this impact my care?
If you have any known lung cancer biomarkers, your doctor can use that information to create, inform, or adjust a personalized treatment plan.
That’s because certain biomarkers, like _EGFR_ or _KRAS_ , have unique characteristics that can indicate the type of treatment you’re more likely to respond to. This can help determine your eligibility for targeted therapy, how you might respond to immunotherapies — and it can help eliminate treatment options that are less likely to be effective.
card
### When do I talk to a doctor?
Ask about biomarker testing as soon as you’re diagnosed with lung cancer, if you start discussing new treatments, or when switching your treatment.
Having the conversation early can help put you on a better, more informed path, which can be important for quick-spreading sub types of lung cancer, like Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC).
As you talk more with your doctor, they may recommend comprehensive biomarker testing that looks for all recommended mutations at once, instead of single-gene testing that looks for one biomarker at a time.
card
### What do I need to start asking about testing?
We know talking about biomarkers can feel overwhelming. Knowing what to ask, and having a few talking points ready, can help.
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")
content
### **Here’s how they’re tested.**
card-1-toggle-label
Liquid Biopsies
card-2-toggle-label
Tissue Biopsies
card
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_14f588fea8dc581156058534f5489c02e81d4dda1.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
### **Liquid Biopsies**
As a first strategy, a liquid biopsy is used in 76.5% of all lung cancer cases. This analyzes bits of tumor material found in bodily fluids.
Liquid biopsies are usually done with a blood draw in a clinic or your doctor’s office, and are less invasive, faster to complete, and easier to repeat than tissue biopsies.
They can reveal some of the same information as tissue testing, but it has its limits — the results may not always match tissue biopsies and may miss some cancer changes.
card
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_1dd7e4aadef4c4f5643d7b310e677dc2b75b029ba.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
### **Tissue Biopsies**
Testing can also be done with a tissue biopsy, a procedure where a small piece of your lung cancer tumor is taken for closer examination.
While doctors can extract a lot of information from a liquid biopsy, a tissue analysis remains the gold standard. It measures how much your cancer has progressed, checks for mutations in a tumor’s genes and proteins, and can point to targeted therapies — or predict if immunotherapy may work for you.
However, it’s also more invasive. It may require an overnight stay at the hospital after a surgical procedure to collect a tissue sample.

content
Talk to your doctor
### Your tailored treatment plan really begins with a conversation.
When it comes to treating your lung cancer, asking about biomarker testing early can make a big impact on your care. Even if this process is unfamiliar, your doctor can help you understand your options and move forward with clarity.
buttons
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")
_content_
## Still have questions?
_card_
### **What biomarkers do doctors look for in lung cancer?**
Some important lung cancer biomarkers are **EGFR** , **KRAS** , **BRAF** , **ALK** , and **PD-L1**. But there are several other biomarkers that your doctor may test for as well.
_card_
### **Where do I go to get tested?**
Where you begin biomarker testing will depend on your need for a liquid biopsy or tissue biopsy.
In most lung cancer cases, initial testing begins with a liquid biopsy that can be done with a blood draw. Because blood draws are simpler procedures, they’re often completed in a doctor’s office or clinic.
If a more invasive tissue biopsy is required, you can expect small samples of your lung tumor to be surgically removed at a hospital, which may require an overnight stay.
_card_
### **What should I understand about my test results?**
When you get your test results, your doctor will go over them with you to help you understand what they mean and how they can be used to determine your treatment options. You’ll most likely discuss:
  * What biomarkers were found — or if no biomarkers showed up
  * What treatment options match those specific biomarkers, and which ones may be available to you
  * If there aren’t treatment matches — what potential clinical trials may be available for those biomarkers, or other treatment options


_card_
### **Will I need to get retested?**
Depending on how well your current treatment is working, your doctor may want to have you retested for any changes to your disease and the biomarkers that may show up.
Since changes can occur over time, it can reveal the way your tumor is growing or changing, or if it’s developing a resistance to treatment.
New biomarkers can indicate alternative treatment options that may work more effectively.
_card_
### **Are there communities and advocacy groups I can join?**
There are many patient advocacy and support groups in the lung cancer community. Here are a couple to get you started with connecting to other patients and caregivers, as well as resources to support you during your journey:
<https://www.lungevity.org>  
  
<https://go2.org>

# Prostate cancer can raise questions. Tests can help answer.
Body
Prostate cancer affects millions of men, with cases rising as the population gets older. It may be considered a common cancer, but biomarker testing can identify the traits that make each subtype unique.  
  
It helps doctors move from one-size-fits-all care to personalized treatment plans, like targeted therapy — a type of cancer treatment that targets the ways cancer cells grow, divide, and spread. Even if you get tested and don’t have any biomarkers, that’s ok. It’s still important for getting your care team more informed and can help them evaluate treatment options.

content
About biomarker testing
## What are prostate cancer biomarkers?
Cancer biomarkers are small signals in tumor cells, like gene changes or certain levels of proteins, that can show how your cancer behaves and how it may change, grow, or respond to treatment. Even two people with the same type of prostate cancer can have very different biomarkers.  
  
By testing for them, your care team can create an individualized treatment plan — and adjust it if the disease changes over time. As one example, PSA (the most common prostate cancer biomarker) can help identify the care to get ahead of an advancing disease.
content
## Let’s go over a few of the basics.
Biomarker testing can make a difference in your prostate cancer care. You probably have questions. We have answers.
card
### Who should get tested?
Anyone who's been newly diagnosed with prostate cancer, or is starting new or alternative care, should ask about biomarker testing.
It's important to test for biomarkers before the cancer has moved beyond the prostate. By looking at the makeup of your cancer, testing can help predict whether the tumor will grow slowly or aggressively — and can help your doctor assess the risk of recurrence if you've already had surgery to remove tumor tissue.
card
### What will my results show?
In prostate cancer, biomarker testing can show your subtype and reveal if you have actionable biomarkers that can guide more personalized care.
That's because certain biomarkers, like _PCA3_ , have unique characteristics that can indicate the type of cancer treatment you're likely to respond to. This can help determine your eligibility for targeted therapy, how you might respond to immunotherapies — and help reduce the need for repeated biopsies.
It’s important to test for biomarkers, even if the results are inconclusive or negative. Your doctor may recommend getting retested, and it helps them evaluate all your care options.
card
### Does this impact my care?
If you have any known prostate cancer biomarkers, your doctor can use that information to create, inform, or adjust a personalized treatment plan.
Testing ultimately reveals the unique qualities that determine your eligibility for targeted therapy, and it predicts how you may respond to immunotherapy. It can also inform treatment intensity, so you can be matched with the most effective treatment plan — while removing ineffective options.
card
### When do I talk to a doctor?
Ask about biomarker testing as soon as you’re diagnosed with prostate cancer, if you start discussing new treatments, or when switching your treatment.
As you talk more, your doctor may recommend comprehensive biomarker testing that looks for all recommended mutations at once, instead of single-gene testing that looks for one biomarker at a time over a longer period.
card
### What do I need to start asking about testing?
We know talking about biomarkers can feel overwhelming. Knowing what to ask, and having a few talking points ready, can help.
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")
content
### **Here’s how they’re tested.**
card-1-toggle-label
Liquid Biopsies
card-2-toggle-label
Tissue Biopsies
card
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_1fb08037f8f4c5350dfd9d690129548e9b8ac2bbc.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
### Liquid Biopsies
Liquid biopsies analyze traces of prostate cancer found in blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, and saliva.  
  
Simpler samples, especially urine or blood, can usually be taken at a clinic or your doctor’s office. Since these types of biopsies are typically less invasive, they’re also faster to complete and repeat than a tissue biopsy.  
  
While liquid biopsies can provide similar insights as tissue testing, it still has its limits — the results may not always match tissue biopsies and may miss some cancer changes.
card
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_150285dd5b753f80763c5062b2330eff88dafaa26.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
### Tissue Biopsies
Tissue biopsies analyze the cells from a small sample of your prostate cancer to understand its stage, subtype, and mutations.  
  
Bits of tissue are removed from the prostate with a needle before a pathologist examines them in a lab. They’ll measure how much your cancer has progressed, check for gene and protein mutations that could point to targeted therapies, and check if immunotherapy may work for you.  
  
Tissue biopsies are usually an outpatient procedure and do not require an overnight stay, however there are more invasive tissue biopsies that may require a hospital visit.

Talk to your doctor
### Your tailored treatment plan really begins with a conversation.
When it comes to treating your prostate cancer, asking about biomarker testing early can make a big impact on your care. Even if this process is unfamiliar, your doctor can help you understand your options and move forward with clarity.
buttons
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")
_content_
## Still have questions?
_card_
### **What biomarkers do doctors look for in prostate cancer?**
Some important biomarkers for prostate cancer are **PSA** , _**BRCA2**_ , _**ATM**_ , _**CHEK2**_ and _**BRCA1**_. _BRCA2_ tumors account for almost half of all prostate cancer tumors, but there’s also a high prevalence of CDK12 alterations. There are several other biomarkers that your doctor may test for as well.
_card_
### **Where do I go to get tested?**
Where you begin biomarker testing will depend on your need for a liquid biopsy or tissue biopsy.  
  
Liquid biopsies analyze traces of prostate cancer found in blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, and saliva. Simpler, less invasive samples, especially urine or blood, can usually be taken at a clinic or your doctor’s office.  
  
Tissue biopsies analyze the cells from a small sample of your tumor that’s carefully removed with a needle. They’re then sent to a specialized lab for examination. Getting a tissue biopsy for prostate cancer is usually done in an outpatient setting.
_card_
### **What should I understand about my test results?**
When you get your test results, your doctor will go over them with you to help you understand what they mean and how they can be used to determine your treatment options. You’ll most likely discuss:
  * What biomarkers were found — or if no biomarkers showed up
  * What treatment options match those specific biomarkers, and which ones may be available to you
  * If there aren’t treatment matches — what potential clinical trials may be available for those biomarkers, or other treatment options


_card_
### **Will I need to get retested?**
Depending on how well your current treatment is working, your doctor may want to have you retested for any changes to your disease and the biomarkers that may show up.  
  
Since changes can occur over time, it can reveal the way your tumor is growing or changing, or if it’s developing a resistance to treatment.  
  
New biomarkers can indicate alternative treatment options that may work more effectively.
_card_
### **Are there communities and advocacy groups I can join?**
There are many patient advocacy and support groups in the prostate cancer community. Here are a couple to get you started with connecting to other patients and caregivers, as well as resources to support you during your journey:
  
<https://www.prostateconditions.org>  
  
<https://zerocancer.org>

### Who should get tested?
Anyone who's been newly diagnosed with breast cancer, or is starting new or alternative care, should ask about biomarker testing.
It’s important for breast cancer because the tumor can grow quickly. By looking at the makeup of your cancer, testing can help predict whether the tumor will grow slowly or aggressively — and can help your doctor assess the risk of recurrence.
card
### What will my results show?
In breast cancer, biomarker testing can show your subtype and reveal if you have actionable biomarkers that can guide more personalized care.
As you discuss results with your doctor, you’ll find that biomarker testing can also help track if your cancer has spread and is responding to care. Even if your results turn out inconclusive or negative, testing can still help your doctor evaluate your care options and let you know if you need to get tested again.
card
### Does this impact my care?
If you have any known biomarkers, your doctor can use that information to create, inform, or adjust a personalized treatment plan.
For example, there are treatments designed to target certain biomarkers: _ER_ - and _PR_ -positive cancers often respond to hormone therapy that blocks estrogen, while _HER2_ -positive cancers may be treated with targeted therapy.
Biomarker testing ultimately reveals all of the unique traits that show if you’re eligible for targeted therapy, and predicts your possible response to immunotherapies. It can also guide your treatment goals, so your plan can be tailored to you.
card
### When do I talk to a doctor?
Ask about biomarker testing as soon as you’re diagnosed with breast cancer, if you start discussing new treatments, or when switching your treatment.
Having the conversation early can help put you on a better, more informed path, which can be critical in aggressive subtypes of breast cancer, like triple-negative.
In the case of breast cancer, your doctor may recommend comprehensive biomarker testing that looks for all recommended mutations at once. This way, your tailored treatment plan can start as soon as possible.
card
### What do I need to start asking about testing?
We know talking about biomarkers can feel overwhelming. Knowing what to ask, and having a few talking points ready, can help.
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")
content
###  **Here’s how they’re tested**.
card-1-toggle-label
Tissue Biopsies
card-2-toggle-label
Liquid Biopsies
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_150285dd5b753f80763c5062b2330eff88dafaa26.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
### Tissue Biopsies
One of the most common ways to test for breast cancer biomarkers is by collecting tumor tissue with a needle biopsy or surgery.
  
A tissue biopsy can find answers you can’t get any other way. By studying the tumor at a microscopic level, doctors can learn what's driving your cancer and if targeted therapies may help.
  
While needle biopsies don’t require an overnight stay, tissue sampling is a more invasive procedure that may require a hospital visit — but the clarity it brings can make a real difference in finding a treatment that fits your needs.
card
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_1fb08037f8f4c5350dfd9d690129548e9b8ac2bbc.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
### Liquid Biopsies
In breast cancer, a liquid biopsy can be taken with a simple blood draw. It's most often used for patients with metastatic breast cancer.
  
Metastatic breast cancer is when the cancer has traveled to other parts of the body. Biomarker testing can provide deeper insight into this advanced stage, and point to specific mutations that are causing changes in the metastatic disease.
  
Since liquid biopsies are less invasive, they’re faster to complete and easier to repeat than tissue biopsies. But they do have their limits. The results may not always match tissue tests and may miss some cancer changes in the metastatic disease.
Eyebrow
Let’s check in
Question
Do you feel ready to talk to your doctor about biomarker testing?
Button
  * Helpful
  * Not helpful

![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_16e193ce9d7b4a69baa025b5828c0e8cdbf29f64c.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium) ![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_131df2b75597a6eca33976f9fedf35c8b6591168d.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
image
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_12bd403bb687ae4404587c2217f0c8bd37e897b23.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
Image mobile
![](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/media_16da9040294b4d7e20383f6a65807972ba180160f.png?width=750&format=png&optimize=medium)
content
Talk to your doctor
### Your tailored treatment plan really begins with a conversation.
When it comes to treating your breast cancer, asking about biomarker testing early can make a big impact on your care. Even if this process is unfamiliar, your doctor can help you understand your options and move forward with clarity.
buttons
[Create your discussion guide](https://www.pfizerforall.com/find-care/biomarker-testing/discussion-guide "Create your discussion guide")
_content_
## Still have questions?
_card_
### **What biomarkers do doctors look for in breast cancer?**
Some important biomarkers for breast cancer are **estrogen receptor (ER)** , **progesterone receptor (PR)** , and **human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)** — but there are several other biomarkers that your doctor may test for as well.
_card_
### **Where do I go to get tested?**
Where you begin biomarker testing will depend on your need for a tissue biopsy or a liquid biopsy.
One of the most common ways to test for breast cancer biomarkers is by collecting tumor tissue with a needle biopsy — an outpatient procedure that can be performed in a clinic or doctor's office. In certain cases, if surgery is needed it may require an overnight stay in the hospital.
A liquid biopsy is a simple blood draw that’s most often used for patients with metastatic or advanced breast cancer. Since liquid biopsies are less invasive, they usually happen in a doctor’s office, clinic, or hospital, with samples sent to a specialized lab for deeper evaluation.
_card_
### **What should I understand about my test results?**
When you get your test results, your doctor will go over them with you to help you understand what they mean and how they can be used to determine your treatment options. You’ll most likely discuss:
  * What biomarkers were found — or if no biomarkers showed up
  * What treatment options match those specific biomarkers, and which ones may be available to you
  * If there aren’t treatment matches — what potential clinical trials may be available for those biomarkers, or other treatment options


_card_
### **Will I need to get retested?**
Depending on how well your current treatment is working, your doctor may want to have you retested for any changes to your disease and the biomarkers that may show up.  
  
Since changes can occur over time, it can reveal the way your tumor is growing or changing, or if it’s developing a resistance to treatment.  
  
New biomarkers can indicate alternative treatment options that may work more effectively.
_card_
### **Are there communities and advocacy groups I can join?**
There are many patient advocacy and support groups in the breast cancer community. Here are a couple to get you started with connecting to other patients and caregivers, as well as resources to support you during your journey:  
  
<https://www.lbbc.org>  
  
<https://www.breastcancer.org>  
  
<https://myfaultygene.org/>

# Factors that put you at high risk for severe COVID-19
Learn who is at risk for severe COVID-19 and what steps you can take to help reduce your risk.
content
## Key takeaways
card
Severe outcomes of COVID-19 may include hospitalization, intensive care, ventilation, or death.
card
People over 50, those with certain medical conditions, among others, are at higher risk for severe COVID-19.
card
For those at high risk who test positive for COVID-19, early action can help reduce the risk of developing severe illness.
card
Practicing precautionary steps like good hygiene, wearing a well-fitting mask, and testing may help prevent the spread of COVID-19.
title
On this page
links
[Who is considered high risk for severe COVID-19?](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/risk-factors-for-severe-covid-19#who-is-considered-high-risk-for-severe-covid-19 "Who is considered high risk for severe COVID-19?")[What is severe COVID-19?](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/risk-factors-for-severe-covid-19#what-is-severe-covid-19 "What is severe COVID-19?")[How to help lower your risk of getting severe COVID-19](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/risk-factors-for-severe-covid-19#how-to-help-lower-your-risk-of-getting-severe-covid-19 "How to help lower your risk of getting severe COVID-19")[What to do if you test positive for COVID-19](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/risk-factors-for-severe-covid-19#what-to-do-if-you-test-positive-for-covid-19 "What to do if you test positive for COVID-19")[Taking charge of your COVID-19 risk](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/risk-factors-for-severe-covid-19#taking-charge-of-your-covid-19-risk "Taking charge of your COVID-19 risk")[Frequently asked questions](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/risk-factors-for-severe-covid-19#frequently-asked-questions "Frequently asked questions")
view-more
Show all
view-less
Show less
content
As COVID-19 becomes a part of our ongoing public health landscape, it still poses a serious threat—especially for certain groups of people.
If you or someone you care for is considered “high risk,” that means there’s a greater chance of developing severe outcomes if infected. It’s estimated that about 75% of U.S. adults have at least one risk factor that puts them at high risk.
Understand your risk and take action if you do get sick can go a long way in helping to prevent COVID-19 from progressing into serious illness.
content
##### **Who is considered high risk for severe COVID-19?**
COVID-19 doesn’t affect everyone the same way. While some people experience no symptoms, mild symptoms, or recover quickly, others face a much higher chance of serious illness.
The following groups of people are considered at risk for developing severe COVID-19:
  * **Older adults:** Older age is a risk factor. People over 50 are more likely to experience complications from COVID-19, and that risk increases significantly after age 65. In fact, the number of deaths among people ages 65 and older is 97 times higher than those among people ages 18-29.
  * **People with certain medical conditions:** People with certain underlying health conditions including, but not limited to, heart disease, diabetes (type 1 and type 2), chronic lung diseases like COPD or asthma, and obesity, are at a higher risk of getting very sick from COVID-19.
  * **Race and ethnicity:** People from certain racial and ethnic minority groups are likely to face barriers accessing health care and, if they get COVID-19, are more likely to be hospitalized, be admitted to the ICU, and die from it at younger ages.
  * **Not up to date on COVID-19 vaccination:** People who haven’t received the updated COVID-19 vaccine are at increased risk of severe illness. Vaccination remains the most important tool for reducing the impact of COVID-19.


To find out if you are at risk of severe COVID-19, take a [Risk Assessment](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/risk-assessment/ "Risk Assessment").
If you fall into one of these categories, it’s important to take extra precautions against respiratory virus symptoms that aren't better explained by another cause. Learn more about [what to ask your healthcare provider if you have COVID-19](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/talking-to-healthcare-provider-about-covid-19 "what to ask your healthcare provider if you have COVID-19").
content
##### **What is severe COVID-19?**
Severe COVID-19 is not defined by one symptom, but rather how serious the illness becomes. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), severe COVID-19 is often associated with outcomes such as:
  * **Hospitalization** for respiratory support or monitoring
  * **Admission to the intensive care unit (ICU)**
  * **Intubation or mechanical ventilation** to assist with breathing, or
  * **Death** , particularly in individuals with multiple risk factors or delayed treatment


Warning signs to watch for include:
  * **Trouble breathing or shortness of breath**
  * **Persistent pain or pressure in the chest**
  * **New confusion or difficulty thinking clearly**
  * **Inability to wake or stay awake**
  * **Bluish lips, face, or nail beds** , which may indicate low oxygen levels


It’s important to note that severe illness doesn’t always happen immediately. Symptoms can worsen over several days, which is why early monitoring and medical attention are critical—especially for those in high-risk groups.
icon
Content
### COVID-19 doesn’t affect everyone the same way. Some people experience no symptoms, mild symptoms, or recover quickly, while others face a much higher chance of serious illness.
content
##### **How to help lower your risk of getting severe COVID-19**
The good news is that there are ways to help reduce your risk of getting COVID-19 or developing severe illness if you do get infected.
  * **Get vaccinated:** Vaccination remains the most important tool to help protect people from getting seriously ill or being hospitalized. Vaccines can help your body recognize and fight the virus that causes COVID-19. If you’re high risk, staying up to date on COVID-19 vaccination is especially important.
  * **Prevention strategies:** Simple habits like washing your hands regularly, and wearing a well-fitting mask can help reduce your risk of getting or spreading COVID-19.
  * **Seek timely treatment:** If you test positive and are at high risk for severe illness, [talk to a healthcare provider](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/find-care "talk to a healthcare provider") right away to see if prescription treatments may be right for you.


content
##### **What to do if you test positive for COVID-19**
If you’re high risk and test positive for COVID-19, don’t wait to act. [Talk to your doctor](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/find-care "Talk to your doctor") right away. There are prescription medications but they must be started early, so reach out to your healthcare provider as soon as possible.
The CDC recommends staying home and away from others if you test positive. When, for at least 24 hours, your symptoms are getting better and you haven’t had a fever and are not taking fever-reducing medicine, take added precaution over the next 5 days as you get back to your normal activities. These include taking additional steps for cleaner air, practicing good hygiene, wearing a well-fitting mask, physical distancing, and/or testing when you plan to be around other people indoors.
content
##### **Taking charge of your COVID-19 risk**
Many people don’t realize they’re at increased risk for severe COVID-19. But understanding your personal risk—and what you can do about it—can make a difference. Knowledge is power, and taking steps like staying up to date on vaccination and acting quickly if you test positive can help you protect yourself from developing severe illness with COVID-19. If you’re unsure where to start, [talk to a healthcare provider](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/find-care "talk to a healthcare provider").
This article is just the beginning. Dive deeper into how this condition is treated and what might be right for you.  
  
[Visit the treatment overview](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/treatment-education "Visit the treatment overview")

## Frequently  
asked questions
_card_
### **Where can I get vaccinated for COVID-19?**
You can [check eligibility](https://www.vaxassist.com/pfizer-for-all/eligibility?exitCode=pfa "check eligibility") and find and [schedule adult respiratory vaccinations](https://www.vaxassist.com/pfizer-for-all/schedule?exitCode=pfa "schedule adult respiratory vaccinations") by visiting VaxAssist by Pfizer. You can also [talk to a healthcare provider](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/find-care "talk to a healthcare provider")—they can help you find a nearby vaccination site and answer any questions you may have about COVID-19 vaccines.
_card_
### **What if I don’t have a healthcare provider?**
You still have options. Community health clinics, urgent care centers, and telehealth services can help you access treatment and support. If you need help getting started, PfizerForAll can help [connect you with telehealth providers](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/telehealth "connect you with telehealth providers") who can guide you through your care options.
_card_
### **Can severe COVID-19 lead to long COVID?**
Long COVID occurs more often in people who had severe COVID-19 illness, but anyone who gets COVID-19 can experience it.

# COVID-19 and chronic conditions: what you need to know
COVID-19 can be more serious for people with certain health issues. Here’s what high-risk people and caregivers need to know.
content
## Key takeaways
card
Certain health conditions like diabetes, asthma, cardiovascular disease, and cancer can increase the risk of severe COVID-19.
card
Staying up to date on vaccination and additional prevention strategies can help reduce your risk of getting COVID-19.
card
Early action is key, so talk to a healthcare provider if symptoms appear.
title

[Certain underlying medical conditions and COVID-19](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/covid-19-information-for-underlying-medical-conditions#certain-underlying-medical-conditions-and-covid-19 "Certain underlying medical conditions and COVID-19")[Common conditions or behaviors that increase COVID-19 risk](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/covid-19-information-for-underlying-medical-conditions#common-diseases-conditions-or-behaviors-that-increase-covid-19-risk "Common conditions or behaviors that increase COVID-19 risk")[How you can help stay prepared](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/covid-19-information-for-underlying-medical-conditions#how-you-can-help-stay-prepared "How you can help stay prepared")[What you can do](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/covid-19-information-for-underlying-medical-conditions#what-you-can-do "What you can do")[Frequently asked questions](https://www.pfizerforall.com/covid-19/education/covid-19-information-for-underlying-medical-conditions#frequently-asked-questions "Frequently asked questions")
